My Dear Friend Garrison: I write from Ireland where I have been received with a warmth I never knew in my own country. The people here understand bondage â€” their own history of oppression gives them eyes to see mine. I spoke last evening to a crowd of nearly two thousand in the Royal Exchange. They wept. They cheered. They signed the petition. I begin to believe that the conscience of the world may yet be awakened to destroy this monstrous system. I wish you could see how the cause advances here. The Hibernian Anti-Slavery Society has been most generous. Tomorrow I travel to Cork, then to Belfast. Every town brings new allies. Freedom is not a gift bestowed by the powerful upon the weak â€” it is seized, demanded, wrested from the jaws of tyranny by those who refuse any longer to kneel. I carry your newspapers and distribute them freely. They are read with great interest. Send more. Your friend and fellow laborer in the cause of human liberty, Frederick.

En me renversant, on n'a abattu Ã  Saint-Domingue que le tronc de l'arbre de la libertÃ© des noirs; il repoussera par les racines, parce qu'elles sont profondes et nombreuses. In overthrowing me, you have done no more than cut down the trunk of the tree of Black liberty in Saint-Domingue. It will spring back from the roots, for they are numerous and deep.

Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere. We are caught in an inescapable network of mutuality, tied in a single garment of destiny. Whatever affects one directly, affects all indirectly. Never again can we afford to live with the narrow, provincial 'outside agitator' idea. Anyone who lives inside the United States can never be considered an outsider anywhere within its bounds. You deplore the demonstrations taking place in Birmingham. But your statement, I am sorry to say, fails to express a similar concern for the conditions that brought about the demonstrations. I am sure that none of you would want to rest content with the superficial kind of social analysis that deals merely with effects and does not grapple with underlying causes.

Die Kritik der Religion ist die Voraussetzung aller Kritik. Religion is the sigh of the oppressed creature, the heart of a heartless world, and the soul of soulless conditions. It is the opium of the people.

Dearest â€” I am writing Orlando for you. The book is a biography that spans three centuries. You are the hero â€” or heroine â€” for Orlando changes sex halfway through. Is that not the most natural thing in the world? Literature has always known what society refuses to admit: that the self is fluid, that love is not bound by the prison of a single body.

And ain't I a woman? I have ploughed and planted, and gathered into barns, and no man could head me! And ain't I a woman? I could work as much and eat as much as a man â€” when I could get it â€” and bear the lash as well! And ain't I a woman? I have borne thirteen children, and seen most all sold off to slavery, and when I cried out with my mother's grief, none but Jesus heard me! And ain't I a woman?

Houston, Tranquility Base here. The Eagle has landed. That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind. Buzz and I are on the surface. The soil is fine and powdery. I can kick it up loosely with my toe.

De litteris colendis â€” Your Majesty, the preservation of learning requires the copying of manuscripts. I propose a standard script â€” what we now call the Carolingian minuscule â€” so that monks across your realm may read each other's work without confusion. Littera scripta manet.

Today I refused to give up my seat on the bus. I was tired â€” not physically tired, but tired of giving in. My feet were not tired. My soul was tired. What happens now I cannot say, but I know I did the right thing.

The problem of the Twentieth Century is the problem of the color-line. Double consciousness â€” this sense of always looking at one's self through the eyes of others. One ever feels his twoness â€” an American, a Negro; two souls, two thoughts, two unreconciled strivings.
